summary: A video introducing and demonstrating the Ponyify browser extension, aimed at 'Bronies'. The video is informative with a humorous tone and explains the extension's features and installation process in Chrome and Firefox.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying a web browser with a bookmarks page open. The bookmarks are organized into categories such as "Apps" and "Recently closed," with a total of 2,008,134 visited bookmarks. The interface is simple, with a white background and gray placeholders for bookmark icons. The scene then transitions to a colorful animation featuring the word "Ponify" in large, playful letters, accompanied by a cartoon pony character and two bees. The animation suggests a transformation or enhancement of the internet experience, as indicated by the text "The Internet!" and stick figures representing users. The video then returns to the original bookmarks page, emphasizing the simplicity and organization of the interface. The final frames show the bookmarks page again, with no additional changes or animations, maintaining a focus on the user-friendly design and functionality of the browser's bookmark management system.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with one male speaker introducing a project called "Ponify" and its purpose of converting things into "brony," specifically websites, stating that there are browser extensions for Firefox and Chrome, and a script for other browsers except Internet Explorer. He explains that he will show how to use Ponify with Firefox and Chrome, and that users of other browsers should watch a second video. He finishes by inviting questions via email. The tone is informative and enthusiastic.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying a web browser with a blank page. The browser's address bar shows a URL that appears to be related to bookmarks, and the page is titled "Apps." The page layout includes sections for "Most visited" and "Recently closed" tabs, with placeholders for app icons. The scene then transitions to a hand-drawn stick figure with a speech bubble that reads "WHAT IS BRONY?" in bold letters. Following this, the text "Wonder no More" appears in a playful, hand-drawn font, accompanied by the instruction "(click link in description)" in parentheses. The video concludes with the return to the original web browser page, now with the "Apps" section visible again, and the "Recently closed" tabs still showing the same placeholders. Throughout the video, the background remains consistent with the web browser interface, and the hand-drawn elements add a whimsical touch to the otherwise standard web page layout.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the basic features of "Ponyfy" and a demo. The speaker transitions to explaining that some listeners may be unaware of the "Brony phenomenon," suggesting viewers read a link in the description before proceeding. The speaker then returns to discussing "Ponyfy."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying a web browser with a white background and several empty boxes, indicating a loading or placeholder page. The browser's address bar shows a URL, and the top menu bar includes options like 'File,' 'Edit,' 'View,' 'History,' 'Bookmarks,' 'Tools,' and 'Help.' The scene transitions to a webpage titled 'Pterocorn,' featuring a logo of a bird and a navigation menu with links to 'About,' 'Projects,' 'Tutorial,' and 'Contact.' The main content area discusses a browser extension called 'Ponify,' which replaces outdated words like 'Everyone' with 'everypony' for a more pony-themed internet experience. The page includes sections for 'Download Links' and 'Screenshots,' showcasing the extension's interface and functionality. The video then shows a dialog box asking for confirmation to install the 'Ponify' extension, with options to 'Cancel' or 'Install.' The dialog box explains that the extension can access data on all websites and tabs, with a brief description of its purpose. The scene transitions back to the 'Pterocorn' webpage, highlighting the 'Ponify' section and its features. The video concludes with a view of the browser's extension management page, displaying the 'Ponify' extension with options to 'Enable,' 'Disable,' and 'Remove,' along with a description of its functionality. The extension is shown as enabled, with a note indicating that it is currently active.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker, who sounds like he is doing a tech demonstration, introducing his intention to go to his blog and download Chrome. He explains that a box should appear asking if the user wants to continue, which he confirms and then clicks the install button. He announces that it has installed, and he will now demonstrate some of its features.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying a web browser open to a website named "Pterocorn." The website features a minimalist design with a white background and black text, and includes a navigation menu with options such as "Home," "About," "Projects," "Tutorial," and "Contact." The main content area of the page contains a section titled "Ponify," which discusses strategies for improving the user experience on a website. Below this section, there are links to download files and a sidebar with additional links and a search bar. The browser's address bar shows the URL "root@localhost:~# cat ver/log/1ife.log," indicating that the user is accessing a local server. The scene then transitions to a different web page, which appears to be a search engine results page for the term "everypony." The page displays various links to websites and resources related to the term, including dictionary definitions, Wikipedia entries, and YouTube videos. The video continues to show the search results page, highlighting the relevance of the search term "everypony" and the variety of information available online. The overall atmosphere of the video is focused on web browsing and information retrieval, with a clear emphasis on the content and layout of the websites being viewed.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing how "ponify" replaces words with "ponified" variants. He provides an example, stating that "every pony" is how "everyone" would appear. The speaker continues, clarifying that the list of words which are "ponified" and websites that are "ponified" are configurable. He mentions additional features that he will address later.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a Google search for "everypoetry" displayed on a computer screen, showing various search results related to poetry websites and resources. The scene transitions to a settings menu for a browser extension named "Ponify," where options such as "Enable Ponify," "Ponify this page," and "Ponify this domain" are visible. The user navigates to the "Ponify Preferences" window, which includes tabs for "General Options," "Replacement List," "Website List," and "About." The "General Options" tab is selected, showing settings for "Highlighting," "Tooltips," and "Pseudo Threading," with the "Highlighting" option enabled. The video then shows a close-up of a text passage on a webpage, highlighting the sentence "does Lyra really want to be human, or does she just want hands" in a stylized font. The scene returns to the "Ponify Preferences" window, where the "Highlighting" option remains enabled, and the user cursor is visible, indicating interaction with the settings. The video concludes with the "Ponify Preferences" window still open, displaying the same settings and options, with the cursor positioned near the "Restore Defaults" button, suggesting the user may be about to reset the settings.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker begins, in a measured, instructional tone, by describing how to modify general settings and restore default settings. He points out that Ponify can make things a bit confusing in some situations, giving an example of the sentence "Does Lyra really want to be human, or does she just want hands?" being transformed into "Does Lyra really want to be a pony, or does she just want hooves?". He explains that disabling Ponify on websites talking about ponies is one solution, but he then states that he has provided another solution.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying the "Ponify Preferences" window, which is part of a software application. The window is divided into two main sections: "General Options" and "Replacement List." Under "General Options," there are settings for "Threads," "Pubsub Threading," and "Replacement List," all of which are set to "Enabled" or "Disabled" with checkboxes next to them. The "Threads" setting is enabled, while the other two are disabled. The "Replacement List" section is empty, indicating no items have been added. The background of the window is white, and the text is in a blue font, matching the application's theme. The desktop background visible behind the window features a blue geometric pattern. The video does not show any changes or actions taking place, maintaining a static view of the preferences window throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the features of a program called "ponify," explaining that it can highlight words and display tooltips. He expresses his preference for tooltips due to them being less intrusive. He states he's been using the program for a while and finds that tooltips eliminate the problem, which is followed by a distinct popping sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a display of the "Ponify Preferences" window, showcasing various options such as "General Options," "Replacement List," "Website List," and "About." The "General Options" tab is selected, revealing settings for "Highlighting," "Tooltips," and "Pseudo Threading," all of which are enabled. The background features a blue geometric pattern. The scene transitions to a web browser window with a search query for "everypony" on Google, displaying search results including links to "Dictionary.com," "everypony.net," and "Wikipedia." The user navigates through the search results, highlighting different links. The video then returns to the "Ponify Preferences" window, where the user interacts with the settings, specifically toggling the "Highlighting" option. The video concludes with the "Ponify Preferences" window still open, showing the updated settings.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by describing the process of highlighting and using tooltips, followed by an explanation of how it works. The speaker then transitions into describing tooltip usage, before introducing a new setting option. He notes the general settings available, while suggesting pseudo-threading. He concludes by pointing the audience to advanced documentation on his blog and recommending it for performance.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying the "Ponify Preferences" window, which is a settings interface for a software application. The window is divided into several tabs, including "General Options," "Replacement List," "Website List," and "About." The "General Options" tab is initially selected, showing settings for enabling/disabling features such as "Traders," "Pubsub Threading," and "Replacement List." The "Replacement List" tab is then selected, revealing a list of words and their corresponding replacements, such as "Find" replaced with "amareica" and "boy" replaced with "colt." The "Website List" tab is also shown, with options to blacklist or whitelist websites, and a checkbox for "Websites" is visible. The video then transitions to a Google search results page for the query "everypony," displaying various links related to the term, including "Everyporly," "Everyporly," "Everyporly," and "Everyporly." The search results include links to websites, videos, and other content related to "everypony," with the Google logo and search bar visible at the top of the page. The video concludes with the Google search results page still displayed on the computer screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker, initially expressing eagerness to proceed quickly with the discussion to avoid rambling and creating an overly long video. He then explains the replacement list section of a program, elaborating on how to add, remove, and manage words to be "ponified." Continuing, he discusses the website list feature, explaining the options for white-listing and black-listing websites. Finally, he mentions the convenience of enabling and disabling the "ponify" function using the toolbar icon, also allowing for easy addition of websites to the list. He transitions to discussing the program in Firefox, sounding informative and clear.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a white screen displaying the text "Pterocorn Presents" in a handwritten style, followed by "Ponyfy" in a similar font. The scene transitions to a computer screen showing a web browser with the URL "http://ponyfy.com" and the title "Ponyfy Extension." The browser window displays a webpage with the title "Ponyfy" and a description of the Ponyfy browser extension, which allows users to replace words with synonyms. The webpage includes sections for "Download Links" and "Screenshots," with a screenshot of the "Ponyfy Preferences" window. The user navigates to the "Ponyfy Preferences" window, showing options for "General Options," "Replacement List," and "Website List." The user then clicks on the "Replacement List" tab, revealing a list of words and their synonyms, such as "everyone" being replaced with "everybody." The user selects the "everyone" entry and clicks the "Remove" button, then clicks "OK" to close the preferences window. The user then types "everyone" into the browser's address bar, and the search results page displays various links related to the word "everyone." The video concludes with a white screen displaying the text "email me..." followed by the email address "pterocorn@gmx.co.uk" in a handwritten style.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features one male speaker with a calm, informative tone discussing the features and installation process of the Firefox add-on, emphasizing its similarity to the Chrome version. He guides listeners to his blog, mentions the download link, and describes installation confirmation. He instructs listeners to restart Firefox after installing the add-on, and he explains how to navigate the preferences. Concluding the clip, the speaker invites viewers to send questions via email, subscribe to his channel, and visit his blog, thanking them for watching.
